column8: The lineage of the kings of Yatse is drawn from the so-called Dullu inscription, the most comprehensive list of the dynasty so far located in an Indic source. This inscription is recorded on a stele (kīrtistambha), roughly 2.5 metres tall, which gives a dynastic list that matches that found in Tibetan chronicles. At the top of the stele is a Buddhist symbol and the famous invocation to Avalokiteshvara — Om mani padme hum — the inscription also bears the name of the scribe who composed it, who sometimes attempts brief outburst of verse inspired by conventional Indian themes. Although, the links Indian culture were slight, what is interesting is that the connection and cohabitation of Hindu cultural tradition and Buddhist symbols are on the same stele. // In Adhikary's work the inscription is B-27.

column8: Despite being the oldest temple in Surkhet, Kakre Vihar remained concealed in the forest for centuries, only to be rediscovered by archaeologists in the 20th century. // The excavation and renovation of the temple commenced over five decades ago, following a visit by King Birendra Bir Bikram Shah, who allocated resources for its protection and restoration. The choice of the name of Kankra Vihar may be sigmificant. Vihar is the term used in India for monastery and Kankre is a phonetic variant on the term chakra, used in an integral part of Buddhist Tantra. The name suggests that worship at the temple might have involved the three Buddhist chakras and was part of what Adrian Snodgrass calls the 'interior ascent.' The proposition is strengthened by more than 200 pillars stones found along the ancient pilgrimage route from India to Surkhet and nortwards to Simikot, Taklakot, Kailash. 40% of these pillar stones have Buddhist texts or symbols (1). The exact provenance of the temple and its building date are uncertain but it seems probable that it was built in the 13th century by one of the Khasa Kings, possibly Ashoka Challa. It was a time when Buddhism was still the paramount religion in West Nepal though slowly falling under the influence of Hinduism. Nonetheless, it is clear from the deities carved for the new temple that it was intented to celebrate and promote Buddhism and also, in an even-handed way op recognize the importance of Hinduism (2).

column8: The fort site is close to the road running from bazaar to Laitikoli. Its strategic position is thus self-evident. It is well placed to control all movments in and out of the town, especially travellers, traders pilgrims proceeding to and from Dullu / Dailekh, and also to India. It was therefore politically and commerically important as well as having a defensive role in respect of Dullu, the winter palace of the Khas Malla (18). We also speculated on whether it had been built at the same time as Latikoili temple when the then rulers of Dailekh had built or refurbished an earlier version in 1582.According to Joshi, a one line stone inscription which mentions the name 'Ananda Malla'  was found in the Mangalgadhi complex, though it does not appear to bear any date or other detail. It can be inferred that it was already constructed during the reign of Ananda Malla who as the second son of Asoka Challa and the brother of Jitari Malla. If this statement is true or if new information becomes avaliable to verify this claim, then it can be said that the fort was constructed during the time of the Khasa Malla. In which case, both temples would most likely have been built after the fall of Kankre Vihar, or at least one of them. This would give a possible building sequence as: Kankra Vihar (13th - 14th century AD), Mangalgadhi (15th century AD), and than Latikoili (16th century AD) (19).

column7: Padukasthan is a complex of temples / sculptures / architectural elements lying around. Once you enter and descend down the stairs you reach a collection of small shivalingas and reliefs of gods scattered around. Notably, on the day of our visit, most of the sculptures had oil applied on them, which according to the caretaker of the temple was to make them look nice. There are multiple shivalingas on the floor, and what looked to the the capitals of the Khasa pillars. One theory I am starting to develop is that the Khasa pillars might have been repurposed and potentially made into shivalingas. There were also reliefs of gods, which look much more inidigenous in comparison to modern, more standardized images of Hindu gods. Most significantly, there is a Buddha relief, in the bhumisparsha mudra, and sitting on a geometrical lotus base, carved on to a niche. This Buddha does not look like the one found in Kankrevihar, which according to Andolfatto is in the Mark-Gujjar style, but has a much more slender and geometrical composition. The inscriptions seems to read that it was from the time of Krachalla. Interestingly, the priest of the temple said that the Buddha relief was not always there and that it was Yogi Narharinath, after a dream, that got the villagers together and moved the relief from the river bank to where it is now. Yogi Narharinath also said that there were 3 more. All of these according to the priest / caretaker were on the banks of the river, but were washed away when there was a flood in 2007 BS. The caretaker point out parts of an old temple that still lay face down along the river banks — this might be an interesting place to do an archaeological excavation. As you go down there is a tree, which has a collection of broken sculptures, ranging from the bottom half of a Buddha in the bhumisparsha mudra, the bottom half of a shiva, multiple bulls, lions that are very similar to the ones I saw in front of the Dullu museum, and circular stones with an imprint of what looks like the dharma chakra / loutses. There are also a litany of Hindu gods — like the Suryamukhi — in very good condition in the same area. Once you take a left from the living quarters of the priest / caretaker, you reach the modern jwala ghar (which no longer has a jwala or flame) and was built during a visit by King Birendra. Interestingly, anything that is old is credited to the Pandavs. All the stone slabs around the Padukasthan complex are remains of the old jwala ghar. Slightly behind the jwala ghar is the bottom half of a dewal — top half seems to have fallen off. If you keep walking, without turning towards the jwala ghar — there is another enclosure with a collection of sculptures and more louts bases. I've taken photos of the spiral motifs on the pillars — will be worth it to compare with the other pillars I've come across and see if there was some sort of uniformity in design.

Measurements: Pillar 1 (25x113) / Pillar 2 (25x121) / Pillar 3 (24x179) / Pillar 4 (28x250) / Pillar 5 (27x195) / Pillar 6 (30x140) / Pillar 7 (30x130).

Two pillars in the  Khasa typology — capital has a spear tip. Pillar 1 (first on the road) is 30x224. Pillar 2 (second on the road)— has motifs that are  very clear — triangle at the base with 4-pointed knots going up) is 30x220.

4 pillars on top of a hill. 3 of them display the Khasa Malla typology with the one behind slightly smaller and bent. Pillars once seemed to have inscriptions on the them. When approaching up the hill — Pillar 1 (30x150) / Pillar 2 (32x156) / Pillar 3 (37x154) / Pillar 4 — behind the 3 (28x137).

Set of two pillars near the main bazaar. Both are in the Khasa Malla typology. Pillar 1 (shorter one also the first one when approaching from the road) has what looks like a person carved into the back.

Two steles (most likely had writing on them but are not legible anymore). One of them in proportion and height has a resemblance to the Kritikhamba in Dullu. Pillar 1 (taller one / approaching from south) is 56x222x19 and Pillar 2 (shorter one) is 50x139x17. Locals say that the positions of the pillar were changed (4 years ago).

5 devals in the Raskoti layout. 4 smaller devals circle a large one. Larger deval has had its bricks removed / amalaka is on the ground. One of the devals (behind the center has an interesting set of pillars most likely installed later.
Fort from presumably the time of the Rasikot kings, probably used by the Gorkhalis later. There is a canon from the time of unification.

Narayan Temple — Fairly new two-storied temple built in the Kathmandu style. Sculptures most of the Hindu gods look new. A stone tablet inscriptions that looks to be in Nepali — potentially tablet from the original temple (?). Measurements of the temple are: 33x66x8.

Char Khamba — Four pillars — 3 have the normal Khasa typology and show motifs running down the pillars (triangles / spirals). One of the pillars (shorter one) is one I’ve seen before but instead of being pointy it has a circular bulb at the top. Measurements (when approaching from the the southwest and going from pillar to the pillar behind in a line are: Pillar 1 (30x196x28) / Pillar 2 (23x103x28) / Pillar 3 (24x183x21) / Pillar 4 (200x28x22). Locals say that the pillars were rearranged.

Jharkot Deval / Fountain — Single deval in the Khasa Malla architectural style — bottom has been painted white. Block immediately in-front of the deval has two holes — most likely used to move the stones. There is a fountain with two taps below the deval in the same style as the one in Bhurti.

Jharkot Pillars — 5 different pillars of different sizes. One by the road has sunk into the ground — all follow the pillar typology — wall built around them. Pillar 1 (approaching from the northwest) is 87x24x 18). Pillar 2 broke from the top — the typology can still be seen. (24x100x12). Pillar 3 is in good condition — measurements are 24x164x20. Pillar 4 is slightly bent and sunk into the ground — measurements are 25x86x25). Pillar 5 has also sunk into the ground — measurements are 25x140x20.

Modern Fountain (Dhara) but with 3 Khasa styled pillars jutting out. Two on the left and right follow the typology found in other pillars but the one center might have been added to the complement the two on the side. Only the very top (bulbs) are visible the rest of the pillars have had concrete poured in. Measurements are (approaching from the south) are: pillar 1 (17x23x15) / pillar 2 — new pillar (18x15x15) / pillar 3 (15x23x15).
Top-half is broken and only the bottom remains. This one is in the middle of a field so a lot overgrowth. Stone slabs / amalaka rings at the bottom are similar to the architecture of other devals.

In the typical Raskoti layout with 4 smaller devals surrounding a big one in the center. The area around the Panchadeval has been turned into fields and most of the devals are half broken or half parts that have fallen down. A tree is growing into most of them.

22 devals of all sizes. Once coming in from the entrance (the north) there are 2 devals and than cluster of 7. In the (southwest) there is one deval standing along on what looks to be a recently constructed cement base. Behind, there is a cluster of 9 devals that are larger than— two of them are connected by a pavilion that goes in between them. Most of them motifs are the same lotus found in other devals. The amalakas look like they were installed with cement.

Burti Fountain (Dhara) — There are two taps, one of them is still functional. Flower motif on top of both taps. In front of the fountain there is a water tank that the water is draining into. This looks to be constructed later, potentially on top of an older water receptacle (?).

Stele is similar to the kritikhama. This is commemorative pillar — middle of the stele has a warrior riding on a horse with a sword. Two lotus motifs on the top and bottom. Looks like the locals might have painted the middle bit blue at one point. Measurements are 40x195x15cm.

Follows the Raskoti or Khasa plan (?). The fountain is slightly sunk into the ground with massive stones surrounding it. There are motifs on both sides of the spouts. One of the slabs still has motifs on it. Spout on the right is broken. Spout on the left has been fitted with a pipe.

This is one of the most detailed devals I’ve seen. In the typical Raskoti panchadeval layout. There are niches with relics of what look to be indigenous gods — something riding on what look to be lions (similar to the ones see in the provincial museum) / in meditation poses. Most of the amalakas are intact and on the southeastern face you see above the niche a motif that looks like what you find in the fountain. On the pillars you see animals (animal / human) motifs.

Temple looks new — raised finds via the guthi. Has a golden dome roof with a set of wooden masts running through — changes every Dashain. There are two stone inscriptions on the side. Its names Chandanath for the sage that drained the water out of the Jumla valley when it used to be a lake.

Dansangu Pillar — Stele similar to the others in the Karnali. There is some form of devanagiri writing on it but I can’t really make it out. Looks like a swastika was drawn on the top register. Measurements are 44x105x13.
Shiva Mandir — Circular shaped temple with two recent stone inscriptions in Nepali. Measurements for the one on the left are 50x87x7 and the one on the right is 52x70x9.

Bigare Mugrāhā and Stūpas — Fountain is in the same layout as others but has more motifs on the side — what look to be animals and humans. A tap similar to what you would see in the hitis of Kathmandu can be seen. 3 stupas can be seen— one still has the top capital on it. Stupa closest to the read has an inscription on it.

Khala Gau Fountain / Stupa — There’s a fountain — no longer provide water —  but is in the classic layout. Some motifs can be seen on the side of the fountain. There is one remaining stupa behind the fountain — an old man from the village says that two were destroyed while expanding the road. Stupa is made out of rocks and is in a similar configuration to other ones in Jumla (like the one in Bigare).

Ukhāḍī Deval / Fountain / Pillar — There is a single deval with a fountain below it. The is structurally intact with the amalaka and most of the columns still there. Below the slab protruding outwards, there are two figures / deities (?) with 2 sets of inscriptions below them. The fountain is in the typical layout with motifs of humanoid (?) figures on both sides. The stele has two flower motifs flanking what was most like a stupa (?) and has inscriptions on it.
Garjyāṅkoṭa Stūpas — Two stupas side-by-side built with the same large stones as the other stupas. Locals say there was once a fountain here.

Guṭhīchaur Deval and Dhārā — The tap is a normal spout (seems that it broke — what might have been the spout is in a niche) and is not designed like the others, but the layout is similar. The fountain still has running water. The motifs are also similar to the ones found in other fountains. The humanoid figure on the sides can be seen. A collection of stones can be seen above the fountain — this was most likely the deval. Locals say that the deval was destroyed during road construction
column8: Goha (Guthichaur) — according to Adhikary — was one of seats of Pala Kingdom (predecessors to the Khasa Malla) and later feudatories / governors / administrators in the court. Tucci also comments about there being a stone temple here (p. 40 / fig. 18). // The farthest flung monument east of Jumla is a small temple built over a mugrāhā, now dry, at Gothi Chaur [sadly the deval was destroyed during road construction and the fountain was destroyed and some of it was reassembled as per locals in the area] in the district of Tibrikot, within a day's journey from Jumla Khalangā. (20)
column13: Surya Mani Adhikary — The Khasa Kingdom: A Trans-Himalayan Empire of the Middle Ages // Giuseppe Tucci — Preliminary Report on Two Scientific Expeditions in Nepal (40) // Prayag Raj Sharma — Preliminary Study of the Art and Architecture of the Karnali Basin, West Nepal // DANAM Entry

column7: Bhaṇḍārībādā Stūpa / Shrine — Two stupas with one that has an intact dome and the other which does not. Motifs running all the middle of the stupa have a resemblance with those found in the fountains. One of them has a sanctum which probably housed a Buddhist deity (?).

Michāgāũ Stone Memorial Pillar — Pillar with what looks to be a flower motif (?). Pattern at the top of the pillar looks like motifs in other pillars. There was most likely writing in the middle / bottom of the register but the writing is not legible. Measurements are 37x122x9.
Khalāchaur Śiva Mandira (Temple) — Shiva temple made out modern construction materials. Has an interesting dome at the top — could be trying to imitate Chandannath (?).

Umgāḍ Stone Memorial Pillars — There’s about 8 Khas era pillars — others looks like were destroyed / repurposed as fencing. Pillar 2 & 8 (when approaching from the north) have very well preserved carvings. Pillar 1 (32x227x13) / Pillar 2 (40x183x8) / Pillar 3 (45x130x8) / Pillar 4 - most of the pillar is behind concrete) (56x147x4) / Pillar 5 (51x77x8) / Pillar 6 (37x260x12) / Pillar 7 (40x89x8) / Pillar 8 (60x104x9) / Pillar 9 - top is broken (49x142x14).

Bayalkāṭhiyā Baiṭhak (Pavilion) / Stele — The pavilion is on top of a raised square platform. Like other structures found in the region, it is made of all stone. The pavilion has a hypostyle roof with 2 types of pillars holding up the door which has a short spire rising out and topped with an amalaka. There are two seating areas inside the pavilion. There are carved motifs engraved into the rock. Stele is completely eroded and has rounded dents — which look like they may have been caused by bullet holes. Measurements are 55x185x8.
Dhaulapani Fountain — there used to be a fountain that locals found and took the stones to build homes. No trace of the fountain.
Babira Masta Temple — Modern looking temple built on a tiered pagoda style / Kathmandu style. Pillars also look very Newari.
Babira Masta Temple (2) — Smaller branch of the temple above.

Tatopani Stele — Stele with what looks to be a stupa in the middle flanked on the left and the right by two circular motifs — potentially chakras (?) — and with writing in the bottom that is not legible anymore. Measurements are: 48x200x7.

Tatopani Deval — Half of a deval remains. There is a humanoid figure (?) at the entrance with swirl motifs on the side. There was a saying that if you took a stone from the deval you will be protected by gods / goddesses — so people from outside the village came to take the stones.
Sundargau Mani Malika Mandir (Temple) — An actively used masta temple. A lot of wooden carved struts around the temple with some stone / clay sculptures as well.

Lihī stūpa and Pillar — Half a stupa remains — locals say that it was destroyed and robbed during the Maoist insurgency and that they put it back together. Stele is completely eroded. Measurements are 45x103x8.

Narakoṭa Stone Memorial Pillars — There are 4 pillars — 2 of them are still standing and 2 have fallen down. Pillar 1 (first pillar when approaching from the northwest) has what looks to be a stupa motif with 2 circles above it and has a bulb (similar to pillars in Dailkeh) — measurements are 24x109x 28. Pillar 2 is half broken and has a triangle motif — measurements are 25x129x21. Pillar 3 (on the ground) is 38x218x12. Pillar 4 (on the ground) is 36x370x11.

Bistabada Stele — Stele with slightly visible motifs — there is a beaded outline around the middle of the stele — similar to other steles I’ve seen and the familiar circular lotus / dharmachakra (?). Measurements are 42x124x10.
Bistabada Sikhara 1 — A slight more curved deval design — front of the deval does not have any stones in it. There is also no amalaka in place.
A museum dedicated to the Khasa (?).
Bistabada Stele 2 — Stele is half broken with a barely visible triangular motif, a potential stupa motif (?).

Bistabada Shikhara Complex — 3 devals of 3 different sizes. One in the middle is the largest with two smaller ones on the side. Layout is similar to other devals and two still have their amalakas / a stone slab pointing towards each other — a potential Shiva linga (?).

Bistabada Stele 3 — The circular flower / dharmachakra (?) motif can be seen in the top register. There is writing in the bottom register in Devnagiri but it is not legible. Measurements are 40x165x10.

Bistabada Fountain — Defunct fountain in the typical layout. The taps themselves follow the same style as others in the region with motifs on the slabs above. A new tap has been installed above the old fountain.
Bairam Mandir — Modern looking temple with two wooden poles in front with some similarity to the Khasa stone pillars. There’s remains of an old temple in the temple complex.

Jacha Dhārā —  A functional fountain with only has one tap. There might have been the fountain head more common in the Karnali — one on top of the fountain. It is beneath ground level and has modern concrete has been used to build around the old stone structure.  On the lintel of the tap there are 3 figures with 2 of them looking like the Buddha (?). On the right side of the top half there is a carved pillar relief. A stele with writing has been put inside the middle of the fountain — this according to Prof. Andolfatto is potentially a 10th century CE inscription in Tibetan, which would make it the oldest writing found in the Karnali (predating even the proto-Nepali inscriptions at Padukasthan / Dullu).

Tarpibaḍā Temples — Two devals of different sizes facing each other within an enclosure made out of stones / concrete. One on the left (from the north) is bigger than the one on the right. Both of them have the protruding slab and the lager deval has some sort of humanoid (?) figure right below (similar to the ones encountered before). Deval on the left has been partially buried under the ground and deval on the right is half-way fully submerged. Remains of a pillar (?) is behind the left deval.
Tarpibaḍā Fountain — In the classical layout with the two fountain heads. Motifs on the side and running down vertically — which is new. The fountain is within a metal mesh fence.
Hindu Temple — Looks modern — built with bricks and painted white. The motifs on the door also look fairly new.

Tarpibaḍā Five Stone Memorial Pillars — Pillar 1 (when approaching from the northeast) is broken - broken has a motif that might have been a stupa (?). Measurements of the broken bit are 29x70x12 / of the other part on the ground 29x45x9. Pillar 2 is completely eroded (47x107x11). Pillar 3 is also completely non-legible and has a deep cut running diagonally (52x166x15). Pillar 4 is broken but has been put back together and is laying on its side. It has a motif of what looks to be a stupa (?) with writing above in Devnagiri (32x128x8). Pillar 5 is thicker than the rest — there is nothing legible (51x146x17).
Stele — Pillar is completely submerged on a canal that goes down the fields. Measurements are not possible.

Ludku Pillar (2) — Probably the top part of the pillar slightly down the road. Two prominent circular motifs at the top and a warrior on a horse motif in the middle register. The bottom has a triangular motif which could be a stupa (?).

Ludku Pillar — Pillar is broken and lying on the ground. Design is similar to other steles encountered. No motifs or writing can be seen. Locals say the pillar was on top of the hill and fell on to the road. Measurements are 39x95x10.

Rasipatan Temple — Small hut like structure which according to locals was built in the spot where there was a deval. The protruding slab at the entrance and the stones on top are reminiscent of what you would find on a deval.

Hāṭsinjā Stone Memorial Pillars — Two different pillars. Taller pillar (when approaching from the east) is a stele that tapers down from the top. There is a motif on the top register, and there’s a beaded motif around the pillar. Measurements are 32x145x11. Once you turn northwest you reach a shorter pillar with a very prominent stupa motif in the bottom register, a triangle in the middle register, and a circular flower / stupa (?) motif on the top register. Measurements are 31x95x10.

Temple itself is made out of fairly new bricks but the lions guarding it / other remains scattered throughout the temple were most likely taken from Khasa palace. For example the stupa above the door with Tibetan inscriptions underneath is a repurposed kritikhamba. The bottom half has been hollowed out to create room for the entrance — measurements of this stele are  46x148x20. The lions were found in the Saubada archaeological remains site and brought here in front of the temple. There are also pillars in front of the door (when entering from the main door — the southeast) with writing in devanagiri — measurements are 20x120x12. Shorter pillar — which looks the column see at Jacha — on the left of that looks to be broken. Measurements are 19x58x17. Pillar right behind it — which has a swirl motif — measurements are 18x71x17.
column8: Remains of the Khasa Palace in their main administrative capital Sinja (p.75).
column13: Surya Mani Adhikary — The Khasa Kingdom: A Trans-Himalayan Empire of the Middle Ages (75)

column7: Saubada / Fulpatichaur Shiva Temple — Bunch of remains of an older structure — which was most likely a deval — on the way to Kankasundari. Large stone parts that look like joints / pillars. It looks the amalaka was converted into a shivalinga inside the small tin hut temple. Locals say that these are the ruins of the old Khasa king’s palace.

Sahubada Archaeological Artifacts — The large stone blocks that like the slightly raised ground are most likely remains from the Khasa palace / surrounding areas. A very well preserved lion is raised on a platform and is the first thing you see when you enter from the southeast. Three other smaller lions (?) are also present but are headless. Alongside the fulpatichaur remains this most likely a repository for ruins found at the top of the hill.

Sera Stone Inscription of Ripu Malla — An inscription that documents that king Ripumalla, inspired by the meditation of Lokanatha copied a book — Laghuratnatraya — which "tended to fulfill all human desires." (B-14). Survey — Top half of the stone has a Tibetan inscription (om mani padme hum) with the bottom in the devnagiri script. Writing is still legible.
Kham Gaite Pillar — Slightly slanted stele with a moon and sun motif. There is also the familiar circular flower (?) motif. Around the pillar there’s an engraved line. Measurements are 38x164x8.
Mahadev Mandir — Temple made out of wood. The temple being dedicated to Mahadev makes sense — given the origin story of the lake. Locals say it is 10-15 years old. Only the entrance door is old.

Rara Pillars West — Two steles — one tall (36x173x9) and one shorter (36x74x7). Both feature what look to be the sun and moon motif in the top register. Nothing else is legible. Locals that the location of the pillars was moved due to a landslide.

Rara Temple and Fountain — Fountain in a classical layout with two taps. One still has an intact tap (on the right) while the one on the left has been destroyed. Familiar motifs can be found to the right / left of the tap. Above there’s a small deval (?) like structure with an amalaka on top. On both sides flanking the deval (?) are two humanoid images carved out of wood and colored yellow.

Rara Pillars (East) — 3 steles. 2 of them are intact with the first one (when approaching from the east) being slightly chipped on the top. This one feature the prominent circular flower / sun (?) motif with a crescent below — a potential moon — in the top register. In the middle you see a vishavajra (36x177x11). Intact stele next to it features the similar circular sun (?) motif and a crescent on the top register. In the middle register there is writing in Devanagari (?) that is barely legible. There is a beaded motif framing the inscription / motif on the stele (42x165x14). Broken part of stele 3 also features a beaded motif that frames the inner part (37x149x8). Top part of the stele — which is lying below the broken bit) also features the circular sun (?) motif with a crescent below framed within the beaded motif (43x58x9).

Bham Bada Devaldhara — top half of the deval can be seen rest of it has been buried. The fountain was completely buried by a landslide and cannot be seen. Top half of the deval follows an architecture similar to other devals in the region.

Rugā Maṣṭā Temple — Temple looks to be from the 20th century — made out of stone / wood / tin and than plastered over. Wooden cravings on the veranda are interesting — resemble a lot of what Andolfatto writes about in his article about designs / motifs. One of the motifs is a sun that has face / mustache — reminiscent of  the old Nepali flag.

Ghāṭa Pillars — First stele (the one standing) when approaching from the east) is in good condition. It has the beads framing the writing and motifs. There is the familiar circular sun (?) and crescent moon (?) motif with the visvavajra below on the top register. The bottom part of the stele has writing on it which looks to be in Devanagari. Measurements are 32x153x15. Once you walk up the incline (towards the newly contracted school) there’s 5 more steles. Most of them have eroded but the circular sun (?) motif and crescent moon (?) look to be on pillars 3 and 4. Pillar 4 looks to have some writing on it that is not legible anymore. Given that the pillars are facing northeast towards the river, it is not possible to take full photos of them from the front. Two other steles — one pillar 7 is mostly embedded into the ground below and is hanging from the cliff / pillar 8 is on the side of the road — these two could not be measured. Pillar 2 (40x121x13) / pillar 3 (32x166x15) / pillar 4 (35x160x12) / pillar 5 (41x112x12) / pillar 6 — only the bottom half remains with the middle bit seeming to be the piece next to pillar 4 (36x63x14).

Kālikā Mālikā Mandira — Temple itself is new but there was an older temple here. Parts of the old temple can be seen scattered around the temple. There’s one pillar in front of the red temple — it is a bit broken at the top and has a wooden short pole in front of it. Beaded framing motif and crescent / circular sun (?) motif present. Measurements are 30x107x15. There’s one stone sculpture that’s been painted white next to the new white temple on the left.

Bham Bada / Old Kolikholā Pillar — The locals moved the Kholikhola pillar from its original location to the house of the secretary (sachib) Nanda Bahadur Malla. It is currently being worshipped by the members of the household as Shiva. The stele itself is in good decision and a bas relief carving of a stupa can still be seen. Measurements are 49x100x(not possible due to it being inside an enclosure but breadth is most likely 8-10).

Bham Bada Devaldhara — Top half of the deval can be seen rest of it has been buried. The fountain was completely buried by a landslide and cannot be seen. Top half of the deval follows an architecture similar to other devals in the region.

Kos Pillars — The pillar has been broken into two parts. There is a beaded motif around the stele. Bottom pillar has the sun (?) and moon motif and a triangle stupa (?) motif. Locals say that there were more pillars but people took them to their houses.
Kos Pillar (2) — Small stone tablet with an inscription that Nanda Bahadur Mahatara found while digging to build his house. The inscription seems to say Bikram Samvat. Measurements are 25x46x3.
